Scrims

A Scrim (in a theater setting) is a piece of gauze cloth that appears opaque until lit from behind, used as a screen or backdrop. In a web development context, scrims are the background colors that are approved for usage. They can be applied to a section of a page, many sections, or an entire page.

When thinking about our applications as a stage where actors (components) are placed on a canvas (stage), and move (animate) as they're interacted with, we can draw a parallel also to how the stage looks: i.e. the background, or scrim.

Scrims are by default have the following settings:

  1. overflow: hidden;, but you can override this by passing in a CSS property to --tsla-scrim-overflow if you for some reason need to update.
  2. No padding/margin. They simply contain the approved color.
